Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Higher priority for search results of reserved prefixes" (#4986) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @ENikS on November 5, 2017 17:31_

It would be nice if package search returned results for registered prefixes on top of the search list. For example if I search for package ``Unity``, which is reserved prefix, it returns 500+ results with other packages mixed in into the list:
```
Unity
...
Unity.Configuration
Prism.Unity                     <-- should not be here
Unity.ServiceLocation
...
``` 
It would be nice if prefix would be recognized and given higher priority 

```
Unity
Unity.*
...
Rest.Of.The.Packages
``` 



_Copied from original issue: NuGet/Home#6142_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet.Server won't work with Azure Active Directory" (#4771) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Dear,

This issue is about https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Server which refers this repo to open issues.

I've tried NuGet.Server locally and on Azure App Service without problems, but, when I enable Azure Active Directory on my App Service for authentication/authorization, page opens without problems after log in, but when trying to pull or push from command line, I am being prompted for my username and password, and using the same from AAD is not working correctly.

Is there any reason it is not working?

Thanks for the attention.

Regards,

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Content File not copied using new csproj format + multitargeting" (#6163) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I created a netstandard 2.0 project, then added additional targets for net35 and net45. I have a nuget reference that has a source file transformation as content, which correctly is copied into the obj/ folder for the netstandard target, but does not get copied for the other target obj/ folders, so the build fails.

I have a small sample project that shows the issue, and I found the issue in Visual Studio 2017 version 15.4.3.

[NugetContentMultiTargetTest.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/1464927/NugetContentMultiTargetTest.zip)

![contentfilemissing](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13681138/32701609-ddbd995a-c7a6-11e7-9f60-72155b24b0a8.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Suggestion: Use the package name from Nuget site instead of the name user enters when running "dotnet add package" command" (#6162) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @RickyLin on August 2, 2017 5:40_

## Steps to reproduce

run the follow commands (I run them on Mac OS):

1. `mkdir demo`
2. `cd demo`
3. `dotnet new console`
4. `dotnet add package microsoft.aspnetcore.mvc.core`
5. `vim demo.csproj`

Look at the `PackageReference` element in demo.csproj

## Expected  behavior
`<PackageReference Include="Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Core" Version="1.1.3" />`

## Actual behavior
`<PackageReference Include="microsoft.aspnetcore.mvc.core" Version="1.1.3" />`

## Explanation

I typed commands in all lower-case for faster typing speed and commands were run successfully, but in .csproj file, it would better be `Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Core` instead of `microsoft.aspnetcore.mvc.core`.

## Environment data
`dotnet --info` output:

.NET Command Line Tools (1.0.1)

Product Information:
 Version:            1.0.1
 Commit SHA-1 hash:  005db40cd1

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Mac OS X
 OS Version:  10.12
 OS Platform: Darwin
 RID:         osx.10.12-x64
 Base Path:   /usr/local/share/dotnet/sdk/1.0.1








_Copied from original issue: dotnet/cli#7346_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Improve Support for Custom / Wrapped NuGet Clients" (#6161) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I'm currently trying to migrate a custom NuGet client from an old v2.x version to the latest v4.x NuGet in order to secure long-term support and allow dealing with netstandard packages that require a newer version. Maybe this is just me failing to wrap my head around some concepts, but so far the experience feels like a downgrade from the old v2.x integration. In any case, any input would be appreciated.

This issue is rather generic, so should we identify actual problems to be solved by NuGet in the process, it probably would make sense to move them to more specific issues.

## Use Case

- I'm maintaining a standalone desktop application that depends on NuGet package management to allow users to install and uninstall plugins, as well as update the applications individual components. 
- Some packages are non-standard and specific to the project, others are just your regular NuGet packages from the main repository, and either of them can depend on any NuGet package out there.
- Packages are installed into a local folder, their contents are examined and selectively copied to or removed from the proper application directories. The application restarts, done.
- A core concept of the application is self-contained, i.e. allowing users to keep any number of installations in separate folders, each being independent from both the system and unknowing of other installations.

## Issues

- All existing NuGet documentation seems to revolve around publishing and consuming packages using any of the official clients and Visual Studio. The only helpful instance I found is a [tutorial by Dave Glick](https://daveaglick.com/posts/exploring-the-nuget-v3-libraries-part-1), which is helpful, but only to a degree. There seems to be a **lack of both manual pages and code documentation** with regard to using NuGet libraries directly.
- There seems to be a big increase in NuGet classes the user has to deal with and learn about in order to get anything up and running, most of which remain somewhat fuzzy in their purpose and hidden behind interfaces. Internal designs are all good and well, but some **shortcuts would be appreciated**: Simple package manager with N custom repository urls - do I really need to manually instantiate an `ISettings`, an `IPackageSourceProvider` and an `ISourceRepositoryProvider` for that, all of which may or may not require a custom implementation?
- I haven't figured out a way to either provide no settings, or provide custom / local settings only yet. All of the constructors or static methods seem to load or require machine-wide or user-specific settings in some way, there is no empty constructor, and lots of objects require a settings reference - so **how do I sandbox NuGet inside my application folder**?
- **Not all methods provide a non-async overload**. This is a design choice that may match with a developers use case, or it may not - but since async is somewhat viral, the lack of non-async overloads is an inconvenience with technical implications.
- The **micro dependency model** leads to 15 dependencies and ~30 files in the output directory for a fresh new console project with just nuget, which just feels wrong. Not expecting that my gut feeling will have an impact on architectural design decisions, but kind of need to put that on the list.

So.. thank you for reading this big block of text - feedback and insights appreciated.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Restore nuget failed : Ambigous project name" (#6143) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
# Version details

**Nuget version** : AppVeyor version ( Current Visual Studio 2017 version )

**MSBuild version** : 15.4.8.50001

**OS** : AppVeyor version

**Project Type** : Multiplaform nuget for Xamarin

**Link to appveyor** :
https://ci.appveyor.com/project/AlexTeixeira/askmethat-xforms-controls/build/1.1.1-CI-11-ythksvpb

**Link to GitHub project** :
https://github.com/AlexTeixeira/Askmethat-XForms-Controls/tree/master/src

# Problem

```
Restoring packages for C:\projects\askmethat-xforms-controls\src\Askmethat.XForms.Controls.NuGet\Askmethat.XForms.Controls.NuGet.nuproj...
nuget : Ambiguous project name 'Askmethat.XForms.Controls'.
At line:1 char:1
+ nuget restore .\src\Askmethat.XForms.Controls.sln
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (Ambiguous proje...orms.Controls'.:String) [], RemoteException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : NativeCommandError
 
Command executed with exception: Ambiguous project name 'Askmethat.XForms.Controls'.

```

This error is thrown when nuget restore try to restore all project, it's happens with Askmethat.XForms.Controls.NuGet project.

I check all configuration files ( csproj & sln ) and I do not found any duplicate project name or package id.
I also try to check if any circular dependency exist...

The nuget restore work on my machine ( macOS : up to date ).

If I remove the package ID from the nuget it works. The problem it that stop working when I tried to release version **1.0.1-beta-1**

# .nuProj

Here the link for the nuProj

https://github.com/AlexTeixeira/Askmethat-XForms-Controls/blob/development/src/Askmethat.XForms.Controls.NuGet/Askmethat.XForms.Controls.NuGet.nuproj

# EDIT

I can repro the issue in a machine windows under Windows 10 and Last Stable version of nuget ( 4.3 )
.

The issue come from the netstandard Library :

```
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk" >
  <Import Project="..\packages\Xamarin.Forms.2.4.0.38779\build\netstandard1.0\Xamarin.Forms.props" Condition="Exists('..\packages\Xamarin.Forms.2.4.0.38779\build\netstandard1.0\Xamarin.Forms.props')" />
  <Import Project="..\packages\NuGet.Build.Packaging.0.2.1\build\NuGet.Build.Packaging.props" Condition="Exists('..\packages\NuGet.Build.Packaging.0.2.1\build\NuGet.Build.Packaging.props')" />
  <PropertyGroup>
        <TargetFramework>netstandard1.5</TargetFramework>
        <TargetFrameworks>netstandard1.1;netstandard1.3;netstandard1.5;</TargetFrameworks>
        <RootNamespace>Askmethat.XForms.Controls</RootNamespace>
        <AssemblyName>Askmethat.XForms.Controls</AssemblyName>
        <ReleaseVersion>1.1.0</ReleaseVersion>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="NuGet.Build.Packaging" Version="0.2.1" />
    <PackageReference Include="Xamarin.Forms" Version="2.4.0.38779" />
  </ItemGroup>
    <Import Project="..\packages\NuGet.Build.Packaging.0.2.1\build\NuGet.Build.Packaging.targets" Condition="Exists('..\packages\NuGet.Build.Packaging.0.2.1\build\NuGet.Build.Packaging.targets')" />
    <Import Project="..\packages\Xamarin.Forms.2.4.0.38779\build\netstandard1.0\Xamarin.Forms.targets" Condition="Exists('..\packages\Xamarin.Forms.2.4.0.38779\build\netstandard1.0\Xamarin.Forms.targets')" />
    <Import Project="..\Askmethat.XForms.Controls.Shared\Askmethat.XForms.Controls.Shared.projitems" Label="Shared" Condition="Exists('..\Askmethat.XForms.Controls.Shared\Askmethat.XForms.Controls.Shared.projitems')" />

</Project>

```

if I change the Assembly Name it work again. 
I cannot build the nuget package in the windows machine, I will try later if it totally correct my issue.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Markdown based documentation for packages" (#9) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Announcing support for rich markdown based documentation for packages

This feature has following parts:
**1. Ability to associate a markdown documentation to packages (and existing packages)
2. Understand markdown and render it properly on NuGet.org package details page**
3. Ability to associate markdown documentation content while packing the package, from clients
4. Ability on VS client to show this markdown content.

1 and 2 have been implemented as part of 2017 Interns project and released now. Please provide your feedback on the feature - both implemented and pending parts.

| Spec wiki| Discussion issue| 
| :------------- |:-------------| 
|https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Package-README.md-support|https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/2280|

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Updates to the NuGet.org Terms of Use" (#8) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Today, we’re updating the NuGet.org Terms of Use and Privacy Statement. As we [announced](https://blog.nuget.org/20170907/Changes-to-NuGet-dot-org-service-management-and-performance-improvements-in-China.html) two weeks ago, the NuGet.org service is now a part of Microsoft. The NuGet open source codebase (both the NuGet gallery and the NuGet client) will remain open source and continue as .NET Foundation supported projects under the same terms as before.

We encourage you to read the full [Terms of Use](https://www.nuget.org/policies/Terms) and [Privacy Statement](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=521839), as well as the [blog post](https://blog.nuget.org/20170907/Changes-to-NuGet-dot-org-service-management-and-performance-improvements-in-China.html) about the changes. For your convenience, below is a quick summary.

There are no changes to the way you publish and consume packages from NuGet.org. The Terms of Use and Privacy Statement have been updated to reflect the change in ownership, as well as how Microsoft will process the data collected, and manage copyright and trademark infringement notices.

Our goal is to provide an agile and reliable global service, and we remain fully committed to ensuring a healthy and open ecosystem around NuGet. The .NET Foundation and Microsoft want NuGet to meet the evolving needs of our community. For questions about our policies, please contact us by email at [feedback@nuget.org](mailto:feedback@nuget.org?subject=Regarding%20updates%20to%20the%20NuGet.org%20Terms%20of%20Use).
